title: Broad-tailed hummingbird
text:
The broad-tailed hummingbird ("Selasphorus platycercus") is a medium-sized <a href="hummingbird">hummingbird</a> species found in <a href="highland">highland</a> regions from western <a href="United%20States">United States</a> and <a href="Western%20Canada">Western Canada</a> to <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a> and <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>.
Description.
Medium in size, the broad-tailed hummingbird is in length and possesses an overall <a href="wingspan">wingspan</a> of . Weighing around , the female tends to be slightly larger than the male. Adults of both sexes show an <a href="Iridescence">iridescent</a> green back, white <a href="Eye-ring">eye ring</a> and a rounded black tail projecting beyond their wing tips, from which their name was inspired. 
This species shows <a href="sexual%20dimorphism">sexual dimorphism</a>, which means that male and female have different characteristics. The male possesses a characteristic bright rose-red <a href="Gorget%20%28bird%29">gorget</a>. An identification characteristic is the white <a href="Eye-ring">eye ring</a>. The female can be distinguished from the male by her paler coloration, cinnamon flanks, and spotted cheeks absent in the male.
Taxonomy.
The broad-tailed hummingbird, "Selasphorus platycercus," is a member of the order <a href="Apodiformes">Apodiformes</a>, in the family <a href="Hummingbird">Trochilidae</a>"." <a href="Hummingbird">Hummingbird</a> <a href="Taxonomy%20%28biology%29">taxonomy</a> has not been extensively studied, but its <a href="Phylogenetics">phylogenic</a> division can be divided as a family into nine <a href="Clade">clades</a> in which the broad-tailed hummingbird is a member of the "Bee group" and included in the "<a href="Selasphorus">Selasphorus</a>" <a href="genus">genus</a>. This genus is composed of 6 members taxonomically distinguished based on color characteristics. This genus is characterized by hummingbirds with a plumage containing rufous coloration and a neck <a href="gorget">gorget</a> of orange to purple in males.
Members of this <a href="genus">genus</a> include:
"Selasphorus sasin" : <a href="Allen%27s%20hummingbird">Allen's hummingbird</a>
"Selasphorus rufus" : <a href="Rufous%20hummingbird">Rufous hummingbird</a>
"Selasphorus scintilla" : <a href="Scintillant%20hummingbird">Scintillant hummingbird</a>
"Selasphorus ardens" : <a href="Glow-throated%20hummingbird">Glow-throated hummingbird</a>
"Selasphorus flammula" :<a href="Volcano%20hummingbird">Volcano hummingbird</a>
On a geographic scale, the genus "<a href="Selasphorus">Selasphorus</a>" can be subdivided into 2 groups of <a href="species">species</a>, one living in <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, and a second in the region of <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a> and <a href="Panama">Panama</a>.
Habitat and distribution.
Habitat.
This hummingbird is seen in the <a href="understory">understory</a> or under tree <a href="Canopy%20%28biology%29">canopies</a> of <a href="pine">pine</a> and <a href="oak">oak</a> <a href="woodland">woodland</a>. It forages in open areas with flowers or in <a href="Grassland">grasslands</a> among trees and shrubs. Its breeding habitat is mainly in <a href="subalpine">subalpine</a> <a href="Meadow">meadows</a>, <a href="foothills">foothills</a>, <a href="Montane%20ecosystems">montane</a> valleys, and stands of <a href="aspen">aspen</a> or <a href="spruce">spruce</a>.
Distribution.
The broad-tailed hummingbird is found from <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> to <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, and <a href="Pacific%20Northwest">western United States</a> and <a href="Western%20Canada">Western Canada</a> during summer, while wintering regions are mainly in southern Mexico and Guatemala.
Migration.
This species exhibits partial <a href="Migration%20%28ecology%29">migration</a>, depending on the northern range during winter. The specific migratory route used by the broad-tailed hummingbird remains unknown, although migrating populations winter in southern <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a> or <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> and return to their breeding area in spring. Males arrive first to the breeding range, followed by breeding females. Some populations of the broad-tailed hummingbird in southern Mexico and Guatemala do not migrate, a variation in behavior called "sedentary".
Behavior.
Vocalizations.
The broad-tailed hummingbird produces several different sound patterns. This bird's call sounds like a sharp “cheet”, which is repeated “"cheet cheet cheet cheet"...”. Hummingbird wing beats have also been found to be a communication signal. These birds produce two different types of sound using their wing beat. The first one is a "“wing hum”" and is simply produced when the hummingbird flies. This type of wing beat has a sound that ranges from 35 to 100 Hz, and both sexes are able to produce it for communication. The second is "“wing trills”" produced by the male hummingbird during <a href="courtship%20display">courtship display</a>s. The wing trill produces a buzzing sound and can be heard 50 m away by other males and 75 m away by other females. This sound is produced when air passes rapidly through the 9th and 10th <a href="Flight%20feather">primary feathers</a>. In one experiment, birds without this wing trill lost their <a href="Territory%20%28animal%29">territory</a> more easily to more aggressive birds.
Diet.
The <a href="Diet%20%28nutrition%29">diet</a> of the broad-tailed hummingbirds consists mainly of insects and <a href="nectar">nectar</a> of plants that are “<a href="Pollination">hummingbird-flowered</a>”. These types of flower are characterized by high <a href="nectar">nectar</a> production and red <a href="Petal">corollas</a> with a tubular shape, such as "<a href="Aquilegia%20elegantula">Aquilegia elegantula</a>". 
Reproduction.
The range of breeding locations appear to be from central <a href="Montana">Montana</a> in the north to Guatemala in the south. Although broad-tailed hummingbirds have been seen in <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>, these birds appear to be accidental migrants, with no evidence for breeding at such northern latitudes.
Breeding site.
The broad-tailed hummingbird has a <a href="Promiscuity">promiscuous</a> mating system and does not form a <a href="pair%20bond">pair bond</a>. The reproduction time for broad-tailed hummingbirds correlated with the time flower production is at its peak. 
Courtship.
Male perform an aerial <a href="Display%20%28zoology%29">display</a> to attract females during the breeding season. Males will fly high and dive while producing a trill sound with their wing feathers. 
Nest construction.
In 70% of cases, females return to their nest site from one year to the next. Females build their nest alone, without the male help. The overall nest construction may take around 4 to 5 days. The nest has an overall cup shape and is stuck to a tree branch with spider webs, camouflaged by the addition of an external layer of <a href="lichen">lichen</a>, <a href="moss">moss</a>, and tree material. Nest material can be stolen by other females for the construction of a nest.
Brooding.
The female will lay two white eggs of around in length and incubate them alone for around 16 to 19 days. Nest cup diameter increases as the <a href="Chick%20%28bird%29">chicks</a> age. Chicks are <a href="Altriciality">altricial</a> at their hatch, and will take around 10 to 12 days for feathering. The female will stay with the <a href="Fledge">fledged</a> young up to several weeks.
Conservation status.
This species conservation status is “Least Concern ”, indicating it is not an <a href="endangered%20species">endangered species</a>, having a wide range and moderate population size, although one survey indicated a 52% decline in population between 1966 and 2015. It appears to be adapted to human-modified habitats.
